author: MaximoTrinidad
body:
<!--

For Windows PowerShell 5.1 issues, suggestions, or feature requests please use the following link instead:
- Windows PowerShell [UserVoice](https://windowsserver.uservoice.com/forums/301869-powershell)

If it is a bug report:
- make sure you are able to repro it on the latest released version. 
You can install the latest version from https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/known-issues-ps6?view=powershell-6).
- Fill out the following repro template:

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.
-->
This is a strange one I can't figured out.  The code provided work in all full version of Ubuntu, MacOS, CentOS, and Windows.

But, it doesn't work in WSL Ubuntu 18.04.  

Steps to reproduce
------------------
Code in question has been extractred from a MS Doc link: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/azure/uninstall-azurerm-ps?view=azurermps-6.12.0

```powershell
$AllModules = @()
$targetModule = "Az"; $version = "0.5.0"
'Creating list of dependencies...'
$target = Find-Module $TargetModule -RequiredVersion $version
$target.Dependencies | ForEach-Object {
	$AllModules += New-Object -TypeName psobject -Property @{ name = $_.name; version = $_.minimumVersion }
}
$AllModules += New-Object -TypeName psobject -Property @{ name = $TargetModule; version = $Version }

$cnt = 1;
foreach ($module in $AllModules)
{
	Write-Host ("[$cnt] - " + 'Uninstalling {0} version {1}' -f $module.name, $module.version);
	$cnt++;
};

```

Expected behavior
-----------------
To create the list of dependencies modules  
```none
PS C:\Users\max_t.UNIVERSE> $AllModules = @()
PS C:\Users\max_t.UNIVERSE> $targetModule = "Az"; $version = "0.5.0"
PS C:\Users\max_t.UNIVERSE> 'Creating list of dependencies...'
Creating list of dependencies...
PS C:\Users\max_t.UNIVERSE> $target = Find-Module $TargetModule -RequiredVersion $version
PS C:\Users\max_t.UNIVERSE> $target.Dependencies | ForEach-Object {
>> $AllModules += New-Object -TypeName psobject -Property @{ name = $_.name; version = $_.minimumVersion }
>> }
PS C:\Users\max_t.UNIVERSE> $AllModules += New-Object -TypeName psobject -Property @{ name = $TargetModule; version = $Version }
PS C:\Users\max_t.UNIVERSE>
PS C:\Users\max_t.UNIVERSE> $cnt = 1;
PS C:\Users\max_t.UNIVERSE> foreach ($module in $AllModules)
>> {
>> Write-Host ("[$cnt] - " + 'Uninstalling {0} version {1}' -f $module.name, $module.version);
>> $cnt++;
>> };
[1] - Uninstalling Az.Profile version 0.5.0
[2] - Uninstalling Az.Aks version 0.5.0
[3] - Uninstalling Az.AnalysisServices version 0.5.0
[4] - Uninstalling Az.ApiManagement version 0.5.0
[5] - Uninstalling Az.ApplicationInsights version 0.5.0
[6] - Uninstalling Az.Automation version 0.5.0
[7] - Uninstalling Az.Batch version 0.5.0
[8] - Uninstalling Az.Billing version 0.5.0
[9] - Uninstalling Az.Cdn version 0.5.0
[10] - Uninstalling Az.CognitiveServices version 0.5.0
[11] - Uninstalling Az.Compute version 0.5.0
[12] - Uninstalling Az.Consumption version 0.5.0
[13] - Uninstalling Az.ContainerInstance version 0.5.0
[14] - Uninstalling Az.ContainerRegistry version 0.5.0
[15] - Uninstalling Az.DataLakeAnalytics version 0.5.0
```

Actual behavior
---------------
Is not creating PSObject containing the list of dependencies.
(Only in WSL Ubuntu)
```none
PS /home/maxt> $AllModules = @()
PS /home/maxt> $targetModule = "Az"; $version = "0.5.0"
PS /home/maxt> 'Creating list of dependencies...'
Creating list of dependencies...
PS /home/maxt> $target = Find-Module $TargetModule -RequiredVersion $version
PS /home/maxt> $target.Dependencies | ForEach-Object {
>> $AllModules += New-Object -TypeName psobject -Property @{ name = $_.name; version = $_.minimumVersion }
>> }
PS /home/maxt> $AllModules += New-Object -TypeName psobject -Property @{ name = $TargetModule; version = $Version }
PS /home/maxt>
PS /home/maxt> $cnt = 1;
PS /home/maxt> foreach ($module in $AllModules)
>> {
>> Write-Host ("[$cnt] - " + 'Uninstalling {0} version {1}' -f $module.name, $module.version);
>> $cnt++;
>> };
[1] - Uninstalling  version
[2] - Uninstalling  version
[3] - Uninstalling  version
[4] - Uninstalling  version
[5] - Uninstalling  version
[6] - Uninstalling  version
[7] - Uninstalling  version
[8] - Uninstalling  version
```

Environment data
----------------
<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->
WSL - Ubuntu 18.04
```
PS /home/maxt> cat /etc/os-release
NAME="Ubuntu"
VERSION="18.04.1 LTS (Bionic Beaver)"
ID=ubuntuinstalling  version
ID_LIKE=debianlling  version
PRETTY_NAME="Ubuntu 18.04.1 LTS"
VERSION_ID="18.04"g  version
HOME_URL="https://www.ubuntu.com/"
SUPPORT_URL="https://help.ubuntu.com/"
BUG_REPORT_URL="https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/"
PRIVACY_POLICY_URL="https://www.ubuntu.com/legal/terms-and-policies/privacy-policy"
VERSION_CODENAME=bionicrsion
UBUNTU_CODENAME=bionicersion
```
```powershell
PS /home/maxt> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.1.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    6.1.0
OS                             Linux 4.4.0-17134-Microsoft #345-Microsoft Wed Sep 19 17:47:00 PST 2018
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

```
![wsl_psobj_psazure_2018-11-11_20-36-15](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/48355505-31b61480-e662-11e8-9fd0-750e73d13d4f.jpg)

comments.author: kilasuit
comments.body:
@MaximoTrinidad 

I changed the code to this

``` powershell
$AllModules = @()
$targetModule = "Az"; $version = "0.5.0"
'Creating list of dependencies...'
$target = Find-Module $TargetModule -RequiredVersion $version
$target.Dependencies | ForEach-Object {
	$AllModules += New-Object -TypeName psobject -Property @{ Name = $_.Name; Version = $_.MinimumVersion }
}
$AllModules += New-Object -TypeName psobject -Property @{ name = $TargetModule; version = $Version }
```

due to the property looking for `name` not `Name` & `minimumVersion` not `MinimumVersion`

and this properly returned on Ubuntu WSL 
```
NAME="Ubuntu"
VERSION="18.04.1 LTS (Bionic Beaver)"
ID=ubuntu
ID_LIKE=debian
PRETTY_NAME="Ubuntu 18.04.1 LTS"
VERSION_ID="18.04"
HOME_URL="https://www.ubuntu.com/"
SUPPORT_URL="https://help.ubuntu.com/"
BUG_REPORT_URL="https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/"
PRIVACY_POLICY_URL="https://www.ubuntu.com/legal/terms-and-policies/privacy-policy"
VERSION_CODENAME=bionic
UBUNTU_CODENAME=bionic
```
PSVersionTable
``` powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.1.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    6.1.0
OS                             Linux 4.4.0-17134-Microsoft #345-Microsoft Wed Sep 19 17:47:00 PST 2018
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
For example, the Microsoft Azure function Uninstall-AllModules will not work in WSL Ubuntu 1804 (I haven't check other WSL distro.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/azure/uninstall-azurerm-ps?view=azurermps-6.12.0#uninstall-from-powershell

![wsl_psobject_issue_01_2018-11-12_15-05-01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/48372452-a56d1700-e68c-11e8-816e-e1950def15ed.jpg)

Is this an issue to be addressed to the WSL Team??

:)

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: Certainly seems like an issue with WSL and somehow `[System.StringComparison]::OrdinalIgnoreCase` isn't working correctly on WSL.  Would be great if we can isolate a repro (and one that doesn't include PowerShell :)

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
Thanks @SteveL-MSFT!

When you mean a repo that doesn't include PowerShell! Do you mean like creating a C# .NET Core code?  I'm trying to understand what to do to help. 

:)

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @MaximoTrinidad yes, a pure C# repro would be ideal

comments.author: kilasuit
comments.body: I just tested this on the Debian install on WSL with your code @MaximoTrinidad and it worked all fine so this seems to be an Ubuntu on WSL issue - with Ubuntu using Culture LCID 4096 & Debian using LCID 1033

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
@SteveL-MSFT 

Unfortunately, I can't install .NET Core 2.1 in my WSL-Ubuntu 18.04:
```
maxt@sapien01:~$ sudo apt-get install dotnet-sdk-2.1
[sudo] password for maxt:
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree
Reading state information... Done
E: Unable to locate package dotnet-sdk-2.1
E: Couldn't find any package by glob 'dotnet-sdk-2.1'
E: Couldn't find any package by regex 'dotnet-sdk-2.1'
```
I was able to installed it on my Ubuntu Server 18.04 but not in WSL-Ubuntu.
https://github.com/dotnet/core-setup/issues/4724

So, it may be something going on with WSL but I don't know how to proceed on this one.
:(

![wsl_ubuntu1804_netcore_issue_2018-11-13_14-40-15](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/48440359-b4b89700-e756-11e8-9abd-224d33b39f85.jpg)

comments.author: msftbot[bot]
comments.body: This issue has been marked as external and has not had any activity for **1 day**. It has been be closed for housekeeping purposes.

title: PSCore 6.1.0 - PSObject not been created in WSL Ubuntu
